title: 110_s3596
content: The "Small Business Lending Market Stabilization Act of 2008" is the short title of this Act. It aims to stabilize the small business lending market. The "Small Business Lending Market Stabilization Act of 2008" aims to reduce fees for certain loans guaranteed under the Small Business Act and the Small Business Investment Act of 1958. The "Small Business Lending Market Stabilization Act of 2008" reduces fees for specific loans guaranteed under the Small Business Act and the Small Business Investment Act of 1958. For pending loan guarantee applications, no fees will be collected, and development companies will not collect servicing fees. The Administrator will also waive the fee under section 503(d)(3) of the Small Business Investment Act. Reimbursement for waived fees will be provided if appropriations cover the costs. The Administrator will reimburse development companies for waived servicing fees by appropriations. The payment will be 0.5 percent of the outstanding principal balance of guaranteed debentures. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal year 2009 includes $600,000,000 for loan subsidies and modifications, $15,000,000 for lender oversight, and $50,000,000 for fee elimination. The Administrator will eliminate fees under subsections (a)(3), (a)(4), and (a)(5) with allocated funds of $50,000,000, $40,000,000, and $10,000,000 respectively. If funds are available, fees for approved loans will be waived and payments will be made until the allocated amount is used up. Loan amount limits will also be adjusted. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to include limitations on leasing for small businesses acquiring or constructing facilities. They must occupy at least 50% of the space and can lease out the remaining 50%. They must occupy at least 50% of the space and can lease out the remaining 50%. The Investment Act of 1958 is amended to allow refinancing of existing debt for small business expansion projects, with certain conditions such as collateralized assets and debt used for the benefit of the business. The borrower must meet specific criteria to refinance existing debt for small business expansion projects under the Investment Act of 1958, including being current on payments, obtaining better terms, not refinancing government-guaranteed debt, and using the financing solely for refinancing existing debt or project-related costs. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is being amended to update job creation requirements and simplify size standards for business loan applicants. The optional size standard will use maximum tangible net worth as a criteria. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is being amended to update job creation requirements and simplify size standards for business loan applicants. The maximum loan size is increased to $3,000,000. An interim rule allows the use of alternative size standards until the optional size standard is in effect. The Small Business Act is amended to increase the maximum loan size to $3,000,000 and update loan pooling regulations. Trust certificates must be based on approved loan pools and have interest rates based on individual loans or weighted averages. The Small Business Act is amended to allow for alternative variable interest rates on loans, including a nationally recognized prime rate and at least one other index. The Administrator must select at least one alternative index within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Definitions for key terms such as "Administration," "Administrator," "development company," and "small business concern" are provided in the Act.
